body.p: A medical researcher wanted to estimate μ, the mean weight of newborns born to women over the age of 40.

The researcher chose a random sample of 100 pregnant women who were over 40, followed them through the pregnancy, and found that the mean weight of the 100 newborns was 3,035 grams. From past research, it is assumed that the weight of newborns has a standard deviation of σ = 500. The researcher calculated the 95% confidence interval for μ to be (2935, 3135).
If the researcher wanted to maintain the 95% level of confidence but report a confidence interval with a smaller margin of error, which of the following will achieve that?

multiple_choice.choice: Redo the study, but this time with a sample of size 64.
Redo the study, but this time with a sample of size 225.
Redo the study and choose a different sample of size 100.

response.feedback: Incorrect. A smaller sample size will actually achieve the opposite of your desired results. The resulting 95% confidence interval will be wider rather than narrower.

Correct. A larger sample size reduces the margin of error (for a given level of confidence). In particular, by using a sample size of 225 instead of 100, the margin of error will be reduced from 100 to roughly 67.
Incorrect. A different sample of size 100 will probably produce a different sample mean, and therefore will be centered at a different number, but will have exactly the same margin of error.

body.p: The mean score on the quantitative reasoning part of the GRE (Graduate Record Examination) of non-U.S. citizens has an unknown mean, , and an assumed standard deviation =8. Based on a random sample of non-U.S. citizens who took the GRE in 2014 the 95% confidence interval for was calculated to be (153.6, 158.6).
Suppose now that a different random sample of non-U.S. citizens who took the GRE in 2014 is chosen and that this sample is larger than the sample that produced the confidence interval above.
Which of the following is the most likely 95% confidence interval for µ based on the larger sample?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Recall that when you increase the sample size, the confidence interval gets narrower. This confidence interval is wider (width: 159.2 − 153.4 = 5.8) than the confidence interval that is based on the smaller sample size (width: 158.6 − 153.6 = 5).

Incorrect. Recall that when you increase the sample size, the confidence interval gets narrower. This confidence interval has the same width (158.9 − 153.9 = 5) as the confidence interval that is based on the smaller sample size (width: 158.6 − 153.6 = 5).

Not quite right. You are correct that when the sample size increases, the confidence interval gets narrower and indeed this confidence interval is narrower (width = 4.6) than the confidence interval that is based on the smaller sample size (width = 5). However, the center of this confidence interval, (158.4 + 153.8)/2 = 156.1 (which the average score in the larger sample), is identical to the center of the confidence interval that is based on the smaller sample, (153.6 + 158.6)/2 = 156.1 (which the average score in the smaller sample). Due to sampling variability, it is extremely unlikely that two random samples will produce the same average.

Correct. When the sample size increases, the confidence interval gets narrower, and this confidence interval is narrower (width = 4.6) than the confidence interval that is based on the smaller sample size (width = 5).
